spanish.glosa: cacto cuyo fruto es el sancayo

Loayza also has synonym ajlla|ña

escoger seleccionar

entry.comment: previously akhulli, but new aymarauta and loayza have akulli
meaning more like put coca leaves in mouth to chew

english.gloss: by something in passing and return

spanish.glosa: comprar algo de paso y regresar

form.comment: unusual root, suspected fossilized suffix; see HVY:45

subentry.comment: where did this come from? HVY:96 would seem to indicate that it cannot occur alone and means roughly 'arrear animales' ; see HVY:107 also
HVY:96 based on root ana- which can't stand alone?
HVY:96 based on root ana- which can't stand alone?
apa-ta+ña:aptaña is levantar (the picking-up or initiation of the carrying)
from Jorge P. Arpasi; confirmed by Stuart, "like a sweet potato in flavor, but smaller and segmented, more like a carrot" , "delicious, unless dried"
from Jorge P. Arpasi, see also EIA:109

this subentry, first added to handle Hardman's heroic example Aruskipasipxañanakasakipunirakïspawa is now modified; Hardman's example would appear to be based on the root arusi-, with a fossilized si. see EIA:170 Juan de Dios Yapita, 27 Apr 2000, indicates that aru(ña) is possible, but isn't used for people, but for "el cantar del gallo'

glosses.comment: EIA:109 lists 'hablar' as a gloss, but Yapita would seem to disagree

entry.comment: fossilized si, so acts like a normal 3-vowel root; in such cases, need to show surface plain like this
the si would appear to be a fossilized reflexive -si, but the result now acts as a three-vowel stem, see EIA:170 KRB 27 April 2000

subentry.comment: the recipent (vasa) may have to have a handle
HVY:20 takes large? or cylindrical? objects

temblar de debilidad or por mareo

peinarse de la cebada por el viento

Jorge 19 april 2000 gives janq'itujaru uñtañma = dá uma olhada na minha (ovelhinha/cachorrinho, etc) branco
I expected janq'utujaru and asked him again.

english.gloss: one who has achieved the fullness of his communal rights and obligations, probably via marriage

spanish.glosa: el/la que ha llegado a la plenitud de sus derechos y obligaciones comunales, probablemente al casarse
grupo de personas emparentadas que forman una unidad social con acceso común a determinados terrenos, bienes y obligaciones

english.gloss: bogey man who cuts out your fat

spanish.glosa: estación antes de la estación de lluvia

entry.comment: this is the root, obviously borrowed from Spanish leer, used in Puno, Peru. See ulla for what is perhaps still the Bolivian root

looks like a borrowing straight from Spanish, used in the Bible. Mä jaqinakaw inti jalsu tuqit purinipxäna, jupanakasti magonakäpxänwa. From Jorge Arpasi, 14 May 2000, with the quote apparently from Saturnino Gallego's grammar.
from JPA, 29 May 2000, confirm; probably complex

spanish.glosa: el que trabaja para (o por) otro a cambio e pago en comida, producto o dinero

subentry.comment: säwi = a saying (with &wi suffix that can also mean place-of)
samsu(ña) is just sama with -su suffix (outward motion)
from Jorge, probably a derivation from sama(ña)
compare "take a breather" = to rest in English
tentative entry; to support siku(ña) = one who plays the flute
came from the Web! may be "wait a minute"
see HVY:178 temporal equiv to jayp'u

english.gloss: son-in-law, especially if he has gone to establish himself in the house and lands of his in-laws

spanish.glosa: yerno, especialmente si ha ido a establecerce a la casa y terrenos de sus suegros

subentry.comment: see HVY:174 this one is supposedly a defective positional, but that may be just a syntactic feature;
also from Jorge P. Arpasi--he confirms the form thaki, whereas MDA p 204 shows thakhi; Stuart agrees thaki
Jorge, 21 April 2000, gave example thakicha(ña) = hacer camino

entry.comment: perhaps used only in Bolivia--it was new to Jorge as well--he says that the borrowing liyi(ña) is used in his native Puno

subentry.comment: uñja(ña) also exists, probably uña with -ja suffix

entry.comment: might be a verb "be sick"; Jorge has given me examples usuña usuri 'somebody seriously (essence?) sick" usuta 'somebody sick' state? (pequeno/local, inclusive dor) puraka usuta = 'com dores de estomago' which look verb-like and usuchjayistawa 'you're hurting me' which has a cha that attaches to verbs or verbalizes other things, e.g. utacha(ña) I asked for more info 20 April 2000 Answer 21 April 2000--I THINK that his examples indicate that "usu" is like "uma", both verb and noun

subentry.comment: see HVY:41 raise animals or children
yatiri = teacher is just yati-(i/u)ri do'er suffix
compare to yatiqa(ña) ; Stuart doesn't think that this qa is a suffix
jaticha(ña) is just the +cha causative suffix = to teach
probably +cha causative suffix on yati, but perhaps historically frozen here
suffix +qa on yati??? Stuart doesn't think so
